tripreview.Title: "UNESCO World Heritage Sites - Clasified temple"
tripreview.sentence: Vadakkunnathan Temple ( ?
it is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva at city of Thrissur- Kerala state - India.
Made as per old architectural style of Kerala .
The shrines and the Kuttambalam display vignettes carved in wood.
Tthis is the first temple built by Parasurama, (the sixth incarnation of Vishnu).
Vadakkunnathan Temple is encircled by Tekkinkadu Ground , which is main venue of the Thrissur Pooram.
Shiva is worshipped in the form of a huge lingam.
A devotee looking into the sanctum can now see only a 16-foot-high (4.9 m) mound of ghee embellished with thirteen cascading crescents of gold and three serpent hoods on top.
( it resemble the snow-clad Mount Kailash, the abode of Shiva) .

In the outer temple, there are many shrines a) Gopala Krishna (Krishna as a cowherd), b) Shiva's bull vahana (vehicle) Nandikeswara, c) Parashurama, d) Simhodara, e)Ayyappa , f) Vettekkaran (Shiva as a hunter) and Adi Shankara.
The two important murals in the temple, Vasukisayana and Nrithanatha (Nataraja), are worshipped regularly.
Ganesha shrine is positioned facing the temple kitchen.
The offering of Appam (sweetened rice cake fried in ghee) to lord ganesha brings prosperity and wealth.
In general this will give you a outstanding experience.

of fresh air to breathe which we dont find these days in the cities.

Experience serinity and mediatate or walk around the huge premises .

tripreview.Title: "Must Visit Shiva Temple @ Thrissur"
tripreview.sentence: Any Visit to any temple is a peaceful experiance, however some temples enhances and nourishes the Soul, This is one of such temple.
Early morning and evening time is most apt to vivit this sacred shrine.

Thrissur, the cultural capital of Kerala, boasts of many famous temples, this temple beleived to be the first temple created by Parashuram is situared at the heart of Thrissur and the ground surrounding the temple is the place of a must see temple festival Thrissur Pooram - held during April-May every year, where the representatative deities of 8 temples comes into 2 camps of Thiruvambady and Paremakkavu.
There is particular route to be followed while worshipping inside the temple which is listed in order on the notice board which is displayed, this is followed by the locals.
The Shiva is in the form of Ghee mountain.
The mural paintings depicted on the inside walls of the temple are being resurrected by the ASI slowly enhancing the vibrancy of the temple complex.
Over all the visit would be enriching one to anyone who spends some time there to soak in the peace.
This temple also has Kothambalam a unique temple performance theatre.

tripreview.Title: "A big lord shiva temple in the midst of the city"
tripreview.sentence: Visit the temple early in the morning for the serene atmosphere.
Very Peaceful darshan you can have and can spend sometime inside the temple.
Must visit temple when you are here.

tripreview.Title: "Heart and Soul Of Thrissur"
tripreview.sentence: The temple is really the Heart of Thrissur cause of it's location and because the life of every Thrissurian revolves around this exemplary piece of history.
This temple is almost 2000 years old and get is one of the best maintained temples in India.
The architecture is beautiful.
And the gardens within the temple complex and surrounding it does carry with it a certain calmness and serenity.
The life of every Thrissurian revolves around this masterpiece.
A place you are never bound to miss visiting.

tripreview.Title: "The main attraction of the Thrissur."
tripreview.sentence: The Vadakkunathan Temple which is dedicated to the Lord Shiva is the main attraction of the Thrishivaperoor (Thrissur) district, and one of the main attraction in India as it is having the guinness record for having a participation of the largest number of youth gathering which happens during the famous "Thrissur pooram" which is celebrated annually and it has won in 2015, the top prize in the Asia Pacific Heritage Award for Cultural Heritage Conservation given by UNESCO.
Devotees are allowed to wear pants and are restricted from wearing burmudas and shorts as followed by the dress codes of the other temples.
It is advised to visit the temple with the knowledge of the complete history of it, the temple employees who are present there in the area will assist any one who to know about the same.

There is "moolasthanam" which is a concreted place surrounding a banyan tree, and the significance of this place is that it is believed to be the place where Lord Shiva along with his consort Godess parvaty sat.
So devotees are supposed to keep this in mind before entering the inner sanctum of the temple.
The temple is well connected from the Thrissur Railway station which is nearer for the long distance travellers, and also by bus.

extra ordinary pillar works
amazing and wonderful experience

tripreview.Title: "Vadakumnathan - The toast of the cultural capital"
tripreview.sentence: It stands on an elevated ground which was once a forest full of teak trees, majestically lording around the Swaraj round of Thrissur town, the cultural capital of Kerala.
The Vadakumnathan temple is the cynosure of attraction not just during the majestic Thrissur Pooram, the annual festival held during April-May, which has few parallels in grandeur.
The primary deity is Shiva, and that is what gives the city its original name, Thrishivaperur.
The temple can be entered through the Eastern and the Western Nada entrance and one needs to be dressed appropriately, as in any Kerala temple.
The temple is out of bounds for non-Hindus, so be forewarned about it.
Women can dress up in sarees and salwar kameez and short skirts and jeans are best avoided.
Men need to wear the traditional white dhoti with no upper garment, save a towel or short shawl.
The temple is huge and there is a lot of walking to be done, so better come prepared.
Cameras are allowed, but no shots inside the sanctum sanctorum.
There are smaller shrines of other Gods in the Hindu pantheon.
Said to be the first temple created by Parasurama who is credited with the creation of Kerala.
Devotees have to follow a certain order when moving between the temples in the outer perimeter takes a devotee in natural circumbulation.
A mount of ghee covers the idol of Shiva, and that makes the idol invisible and after the abhishekam, a small part of the ghee is returned to the devotees.

Interestingly, in the temple quadrangle, there are specified spots at which the devotees can offer their salutations to various Gods including Lord Shiva of Kashi and other Gods in different geographical directions.
Unni Appam, a sweet rice cake fried in ghee to Mahaganapathy is one of the unique offerings at Vadakkunnathan temple.
The Vadakumnathan temple is a place where the devotee can also admire the traditional arts of Kerala, with extensive murals, rows of lamps that adorn the walls.
Not to be missed, is the Koothambalam, which is as old as the temple and is the hall for musical and dance performances.
Do ask the locals for the location of the Elanji tree, which is the spot where the famous Pandi melam or Elanjathira melam or musical ensemble by hundreds of artistes during the Thrissur Pooram.
It's the ideal to time to be here, but that depends if you can handle the massive, bone crushing crowds.
It will take you a minimum of an hour to complete the worship and the walk.
For anyone planning a Kerala visit, block off two days for the temples in Thrissur, Vadakkumnathan, Parmekavu and Thiruvambady and then a stay over at Guruvayur for an early morning darshan.
Plus add on Thriprayar and Kudalmanikyam temples that are 30 mts drive from Thrissur.

tripreview.Title: "Must see"
tripreview.sentence: Vadakkumnathan Temple is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva at city of Thrissur, of Kerala state in India This temple is a classical example of Kerala style of architecture and has many decorative murals and works of art.
This is the venue of the world famous Thrissur Pooram Festival celebrated annually in April-May.
Non-Hindus are not allowed inside the temple.
Offering timings 4.30 am to 11 pm, 5 pm to 8.30 pm.

tripreview.Title: "Holy amongst the city of Culture"
tripreview.sentence: I went to this great Shiva temple, situated in the centre of a commercial hub-Trichur.
I went to this temple on an auspicious day.

The day was Thiruvathira and the temple was lit with oil lamps everywhere with the help of devotees and immediately outside the temple, a bevy of ladies were dancing the traditional Thiruvathira dance in the traditional saree that is worn on such auspicious days.
Mind you, the dance was non stop and the songs rendered were simply divine.

there was a spot within the premises were devotees laid one piece of stone on a heap and it is believed that if the stones remained unsettled it is good fortune and auspicious to the person and family.
That was a wonderful day.
It is celebrated on Thiruvathira day in the Malayalam month of Dhanu- generally it falls in December.
an experience worth the effort.

tripreview.Title: "Wonderful Shiva temple @ Kerala. Must Visit !!"

Atmosphere inside the temple was so calm, peaceful, spiritual which provided a great peace of mind for the people who visit.
The main deity of the temple was Lord Shiva covered with ghee, various deities are available around the temple.
Lord Rama, Lord Ayyappa, Lord Ganapathy, Adhi Shankara, Parvary etc.
Must visit temple.

It is a must visit site while you reach Thrissur.

tripreview.sentence: Most reports are by locals of Kerala This is one from outside This temple is worth a visit Many from outside Kerala go to Guruvayoor via Trissur but do not know what they miss by not visiting this temple.
To enjoy it in full you need to adhere to the directions given for visiting the temple.
A proper observant pradakshina of the outer pradakshina as directed followed by directions for the observant inner pradakshina throws up the full potential of the holy place.
I was fortunate to have a local take me through the tour, it took full two hours, seeing the flora and fauna together with the Devine structures.
No other place in India can rival its upkeep and the place is wonderful for meditation under the open sky, in the midst of the historical garden.

The temple opens daily at 03:00 AM, closes at 10:30 AM, reopens at 05:00 PM and closes at 8.30 PM.
Order of visiting in the outerof the temple.
Sreemoolasthanam
Goshalakrishnan
Nandikeshwara
Parashurama
Simhodara
Kashivishwanatha- to be viewed from the altar placed a little to the north of Simhodara 7.
Pray to Chidambaranadha at the small platform at the south-east corner.
Pray to Sethunadha of Rameshwaram looking Eastwards.
From the south gopura pray to Kodungallur Bhagavathi.
From the platform ath the south- west corner look south and pray to Sangameshwara of Koodalmanikyam 12.
From the same platform pray to Oorakathamma Thiruvadi
Look at the domes/ thazhikakkudam of Vadakkunnadhan, Shankaranarayanan and Sri Rama and pray 14.
The one comes upon a flat granite slab called Vyasashila on a platform on which one must write 'Hari Sree Ganapathaye Namah' 15.
Ayyappa or Shastha
Samadhi of Adi Shankaracharya marked by a Shankha and Chakra 17.
Adi Shankara.
Vrishabha
Vasukishayanam painting.
Also known as Phanivarashayana.
One of the rarest murals in which Lord Shiva is depicted resembling Lord Vishnu's Ananthashayana form.

tripreview.Title: "History and Architecture at its purest"
tripreview.sentence: Vadakkunnathan Temple is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.
This temple is a classic example of the architectural style of Kerala and has monumental towers on all four sides and also a kootthambalam (temple theatre).
Mural paintings depicting various episodes from Mahabharata can be seen inside the temple.
The shrines and the Kootthambalam display vignettes carved in wood.
The temple, along with the mural paintings, has been declared as a National Monument by the ASI .
According to popular local lore, this is the first temple built by Parasurama, the sixth incarnation of Vishnu.
Non-Hindus are not allowed to enter into the temple.

tripreview.Title: "The Best temple I have ever been to!"
tripreview.sentence: This Shiva temple, supposedly built by Parashuram is the most peaceful place you can find right at the centre of the city.
The architecture is wonderful.
The temple also has a famous Koothambalam, which you should not miss.
I would recommend to visit during Shivrathri festival so that you can enjoy the decorations and also the cultural programs at the temple.

the best time is morning before 7 AM .

there is a suggested route to visit all the sub temples within this compound.
